docs.snippet: A picture caption on Saturday with a Sports of the Times column, about Luis Suárez of Uruguay having used his hands to block a shot by Ghana in a quarterfinal match of the World Cup, referred incorrectly in some editions to the effect his actions...
docs.lead_paragraph: A picture caption on Saturday with a Sports of the Times column, about Luis Suárez of Uruguay having used his hands to block a shot by Ghana in a quarterfinal match of the World Cup, referred incorrectly in some editions to the effect his actions had on the outcome. His block resulted in a penalty kick that Ghana missed; it did not ''all but eliminate Ghana.'' (Uruguay won in a shootout.)

docs.snippet: Paul makes his choice and renders the actual game-playing part of the World Cup final a mere formality.
docs.lead_paragraph: Sunday's World Cup final was rendered a mere formality on Friday as Paul the Psychic Octopus chose Spain to beat Netherlands in the tournament final.
docs.abstract: Paul makes his choice and renders the actual game-playing part of the World Cup final a mere formality.

headline.main: The Octopus Has Chosen ... for Spain

docs.snippet: News and notes from all over, two days before the Spain-Netherlands finalissima.
docs.lead_paragraph: • Johan Cruyff, the great Dutch footballer of the 1970s who also played for and coached Barcelona, says he is supporting Spain in Sunday's final. "Spain, a replica of Barca, is the best publicity for football," Cruyff wrote in his Thursday column in the Barcelona newspaper El Periodico de Catalunya. "Who am I supporting? I am Dutch but I support the football that Spain is playing." Here is Cruyff dribbling -- a skill at which he was unsurpassed:
docs.abstract: News and notes from all over, two days before the Spain-Netherlands finalissima.

headline.main: Fun Facts to Know and Tell Ahead of Sunday's Final

docs.snippet: FIFA's World Cup awards are still up for grabs heading into the final weekend.
docs.lead_paragraph: JOHANNESBURG -- Spain and the Netherlands will battle it out for the World Cup trophy inside the calabash in Soccer City on Sunday. But there are other prizes to be had here, including the Golden Boot, for the tournament's top scorer, the Golden Ball for the most outstanding player and the, um, award for the best young player of the tournament. Perhaps it can be called the golden learner's permit or something.
docs.abstract: FIFA's World Cup awards are still up for grabs heading into the final weekend.

docs.abstract: Preview of World Cup soccer tournament third-place playoff between Germany and Uruguay; photo

docs.snippet: Sunday's World Cup final was rendered a mere formality on Friday as Paul the Psychic Octopus chose Spain to beat Netherlands in the tournament final.     Working from his aquarium tank in Oberhausen, Germany, the sage cephalopod, whose record in...
docs.lead_paragraph: Sunday's World Cup final was rendered a mere formality on Friday as Paul the Psychic Octopus chose Spain to beat Netherlands in the tournament final. Working from his aquarium tank in Oberhausen, Germany, the sage cephalopod, whose record in predicting international soccer matches since 2008 stands at 10-1, made its choice before a bank of cameras from several television networks. On Thursday The Lede blog explained that the multitalented mollusk's accurate prophecy that Spain would defeat Germany to advance to the final had resulted in death threats from outraged German fans.
